Description: Small jug carved from calcite or alabaster (?); double-reeded handle attached to a rounded rim and below rounded shoulders; elongated tapering body with slightly flattened base and high vertical neck; drilled; smoothed outer surface; rim and base bit damaged; few cracks.
Curator's comments: Naukratis provided a wide range of vessels in calcite, chiefly alabastra which were locally produced (Petrie 1886, 15). A few other shapes were also collected, such as this jug. Its shape is not related to the Egyptian repertoire of vessel, but reminds more Syro-Palestinian juglets (e.g. calcite small jugs of the Late Bronze Age discovered in Kamid el-Loz: Lilyquist 1996, pl. 4). Lilyquist, C, 1996, ‘Stone Vessels at Kamid el-Loz, Lebanon: Egyptian, Egyptianizing or Non-Egyptian? A Question at Sites from the Sudan to Iraq to the Greek Mainland’, in Hachmann, R. (ed.), Kamid el-Loz 16 – ‘Schatzhaus’-Studien, Saarbrücker Beiträge zur Altertumskunde 59, Bonn, 133–73. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884-5 (Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund 3), London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (EA.042) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather fair, though rim and base bit chipped and some cracks
